title: FFA: Why the A-League can’t expand right now
text:
FFA: Expanding A-League by two teams under current model would cause net losses for six years February 28, 2017 7:27pm by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS THE A-League will not expand before the 2018-19 season as adding two teams under the current model would result in net losses over the next six years, according to Football Federation Australia’s analysis of football’s financial position. 
Despite rapid growth of football in general, expansion of the A-League and W-League will require more investment to avoid unsustainable losses. 
If new teams were added to the competitions, the grant distributions given to each club, as well as the increased costs for FFA in operational matters (such as transport) would exceed the additional revenue the clubs would generate with sponsorships and broadcast arrangements. 
As FFA is a not-for-profit organisation that redistributes income into clubs and other parts of the game, they said the losses would not be viable for them. 
However, this week FFA are set to begin developing a new ownership and operating model for both A-League and W-League with the aim of making both competitions more compatible for expansion while also making them more attractive to investors. 
The criteria for expansion and its feasibility under a new model will also be developed in the process. 
“We recently advised the clubs that we must explore a new model for the Hyundai A-League/Westfield W-League. We agree that we need to protect the value of the existing licences in which the current owners have invested,” FFA chief executive David Gallop said in a statement. FFA CEO David Gallop (C). Source: AAP 
“We want to expand the leagues but this has to happen as part of a new structure. That’s why we are now working with the clubs to determine the future structure of the leagues and the criteria for expansion. 
“We will examine these issues in detail and expect this work will take months rather than weeks. We know that those consortia that have expressed an interest in joining the league would want to be part of something that is financially sustainable and attractive as a sound investment.” 
FFA will also engage a corporate advisory firm to help develop models for a new structure and provide advice around the financial aspects of making promotion happen. 
“The decisions we make around the future of the Hyundai A-League/Westfield W-League will have an impact on every aspect of football in Australia,” said Mr Gallop. 
“That’s why we want to work with the clubs and other stakeholders on changes that benefit the whole game.” 
FFA will provide updates on the process over the coming months, and the existing joint working group that includes four club chairmen, will meet on Thursday to discuss this. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
